DIV1.P: THE DRAMATIST, A COMEDY, IN FIVE ACTS.
WRITTEN BY —REYNOLDS, Esq Author of WERTER, &c. AS PERFORMED AT THE THEATRE ROYAL SMOKE-ALLEY.

DIV1.HEAD: PROLOGUE.
DIV1.L: IN this blest land, thro' ev'ry varying age,
Public and private life have had their rage.
In good King Arthur's days, with cumb'rous shield,
The Iron champions pranc'd upon the field,
Relentless beauty bade the knights advance,
And bear the rage romantic on their lance.
From length of time this fury found it's death,
And wiser fashions mark'd Elizabeth.
Her modest dames were form'd of mildest stuff,
But check'd presumption by a monstrous ruff,
Their breakfast rage all delicacy shocks,
Early they pick'd the pinions of an ox,
Then rode in state behind the scepter'd fair,
On horse-back—full as well as my Lord Mayor.
These modes howe'er are alter'd, and of late,
Beef, but not modesty is out of date;
For now instead of rich sirloins, we see,
Green calipash, and yellow callipee;
Now ladies shine from Phaetons afar,
And very soon perhaps may learn to spar;
At leisure hours they work settees, and chairs,
Or waste their youth on puddings, or on prayers,
Each modest dame may quit her cara sposa,
To take a hug with Humphries or Mendoza.
As thus the manners differ, writers try,
To trace the whimsical variety,
With observation just, and mirror true,
Present each reigning solly to the view.
Yet, hold, our author's scene all rage outgoes,
A new, excentric character he shews;
No doughty Quixotte, and no modern fighter,
A dramatizing hero, play—inditer,
One who to gain applause, like wits in vogue,
Torments with Prologue, or with Epilogue.
At every house with incident he meets
And thinks he sees processions—in the streets,
In common life will unities expect
Looks up to politics for stage effect,
And so misled, that if his wife should die,
"She's made a charming exit," he would cry.
But let me not our Comedy forestal,
Or court your judgment till the curtain fall,
Mean while we'll strive your patience to beguile
And win from loveliest lips the bright'ning smile.
Such as it is we give it to your view,
And trust our cause to candour, and to you.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE—A Grove—Lady WAITFORT'S House.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter MARIANNE and LETTY from the house.

SP.SPEAKER: MARIANNE.
SP.P: BUT I tell you I will out—I didn't come to Bath to be conf'd, I won't—I hate all their company but sweet Miss Courtney's.

SP.SPEAKER: LET.
SP.P: Why I declare Miss Marianne, you grow worse and worse every day, your country manners will be the ruin of you.

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: Don't talk about that Letty, it was a shame to bring me up in the country! If I had been properly taken care of I might have done great things, I might have mar∣ried the Pet I danc'd with at the ball, but it's all over now—I shall never get a husband, and what's worse my aunt did it on purpose! She ruin'd me, Letty, that no∣body else might.

SP.SPEAKER: LET.
SP.P: How you talk! I hope Miss Courtney hasn't taught you all this.

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: No, she's a dear creature! she has taught me many things but nothing improper, I'm sure.

SP.SPEAKER: LET.
SP.P: Pray has she taught you why she never plays any tune but the one we heard just now?

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: Yes, and if you'll keep it a secret I'll tell you, Letty; Mr Harry Neville taught it her last summer, and now she is always playing it because it puts her in mind of the dear man, when it is ended don't you observe how she sighs from the bottom of her dear little heart.

SP.SPEAKER: LET.
SP.P: Why I thought they had quarrell'd?

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P:
So they have, she won't see him, and I believe my aunt Lady Waitfort has been the occasion of it; Poor Mr Neville! I wish I could assist him! for indeed Letty,
I always pity any body that has been cross'd in love—it may be one's own case one day or other, you know.

SP.SPEAKER: LET.
SP.P: True, and for the same reason, I suppose you rejoice when it is successful? I am sure now the intended marriage of Lady Waitfort and Lord Scratch gives you pleasure?

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: What, the country gentleman who has lately come to the title? no if you'll believe me I don't like him at all, he's a sour old fellow, is always abusing our sex, and thinks there is only one good woman under Heaven, now I'm sure that's a mistake; for I know I'm a good woman, and I think, Letty, you are another?

SP.SPEAKER: LET.
SP.P: Yes, I hope so, tho' I confess I think your aunt a better than either of us.

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: More shame for you, she is a woman of senti∣ment, and hums you over with her sentiments and flou∣rishes about purity and feelings! faith she ought to be ashamed of herself! no other woman would talk in that manner.

SP.SPEAKER: LET.
SP.P: You mistake her, she is a woman of virtue, and can't help feeling for the vices and misfortunes of others.

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: Then why can't she do as I have done, Letty? keep her feelings to herself — If I had given way to them half as much as she has—Oh Lord! I don't know what might have been the consequences?

SP.SPEAKER: LET.
SP.P: For shame! you never hear Lady Waitfort speak ill of any body.

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: No, how shou'd she, when she speaks of nobody but herself.

SP.SPEAKER: LET.
SP.P: Well your opinion is of little weight—my lord sees her merit, and is come to Bath on purpose to marry her—He thinks her a prodigy of goodness.

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: Then pray let him have her; every fool knows; so to be sure does he Letty, that a prodigy of goodness is a very rare thing — but when he finds her out? faith it will be a rare joke when he finds her out.

SP.SPEAKER: LET.
SP.P: Shameful, Miss Marianne! pray do speak a lit∣tle intelligibly, and remember your aunt's favourite ob∣servation.

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: What is it, I have forgot?

SP.SPEAKER: LET.
SP.P: That good sentiments are always plain.

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: Yes, so are good women—bid her remember that, Letty.

SP.SPEAKER: LET.
SP.P: Hush! say no more, here she comes, and Mr Willoughby with her.

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: Ay, that man is always with her of late, but come Letty, let's get out of her way, let's take a walk and look at the Beaux.

SP.SPEAKER: LET.
SP.P: The beaux! ah, I see you long to become a woman of fashion.

DIV3.STAGE: Entr LADY WAITFORT, WILLOUGHBY and SERVANT.

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: When my lord returns, tell him I'm gone to lady Walton's, and shall be back immediately.

SP.SPEAKER: WILL.
SP.P: Then your ladyship is certain Harry Neville is returned?

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: Yes, the ungrateful man arrived last night, and as I yet mean to consult his happiness, I have writ∣ten to him to come to me this evening, but I will ever oppose his union with my Lord's ward, Louisa Courtney, because I think it will be the ruin of them both; and you know, Willoughby, one cannot forget their feeling on these occasions.

SP.SPEAKER: WILL.
SP.P: Certainly—but Ennui the time killer whose only being in life is to murder the hours is also just arrived, and my Lord is resolved on his marrying Louisa instantly, only because he'll make a quiet member for his borough in the west.

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: True, but for various reasons, I am deter∣mined she shall be yours, yet it must be done artfully—my circumstances are derang'd and an alliance with my Lord is my only hope of relief, such are the fruits of virtue, Willoughby!

SP.SPEAKER: WILL.
SP.P: Well but her fortune is entirely dependant on my lord's consent, and how is that to be obtained? You know I'm no favourite, and Floriville is a great one.

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: I know it—and therefore we must incense him against Floriville—let me see, can't we contrive some mode—some little ingenious story—he is a singular cha∣racter you know, and has violent prejudices.

SP.SPEAKER: WILL.
SP.P: True, and of all his prejudices, none are so violent or so entertaining as that against authors and ac∣tors.

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: Yes, the stage is his aversion, and some way or other—I have it—it's an odd thought, but may do much, suppose we tell him Floriville has written a play?

SP.SPEAKER: WILL.
SP.P: The luckiest thought in the world, it will make him hate him directly.

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: Well, leave it to me—I'll explain the mat∣ter to myself, and my life on't it proves successful; you see Willoughby my only system is to promote happiness.

SP.SPEAKER: WILL.
SP.P: It is indeed Lady Waitfort—but if this, fails, may I still hope for your interest with Miss Courtney?

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: Yes, I'm determined she shall be yours and neither Neville's nor Ennui's—but come it's late, and here he is, we'll get rid of him.

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: Mr Ennui, your servant, we were going to the parade—have you seen your cousin Neville?

SP.SPEAKER: ENN.
SP.P: I've an idea—I've just left him.

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: I suppose we shall see you at lady Walton's in the evening—till when adieu.

SP.SPEAKER: ENN.
SP.P: I've an idea, I don't like this lady Waitfort, she wishes to trick me out of my match with Miss Courtney, and if I could trick her in return — (takes out his watch) how goes the enemy? Only one o'clock—thought it had been that an hour ago—heigho!—here's my patron Lord Scratch.

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: What wonderful virtue in the art of hear∣ing, may I die if a listener is to be found any where— zounds! am not I a peer, and don't I talk by prerogative? and if I mayn't talk ten times as much as another per∣son what's the use of my peerage?

SP.SPEAKER: ENN.
SP.P: I've an idea—I don't comprehend you.

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: That fellow Neville, wouldn't hear a word I had to say! abandoned young dog! he's come to Bath to invent tales against that divinity lady Waitfort, again, I suppose. But my ward Louisa shall be put out of his power for ever. She shall marry you to morrow.

SP.SPEAKER: ENN.
SP.P: In fact I always forget to give your lordship joy of your title, tho' not of your dress.

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P:
Not of my dress! ay, ay—there's the difference—you poor devils in humble life are obliged to
dress well to look like gentlemen—we peers may dress as we please (looking at his watch) but I shall lose my ap∣pointment—past two o'clock.

SP.SPEAKER: ENN.
SP.P: Past two o'clock! delightful!

SP.SPEAKER: L SCRATCH.
SP.P: Delightful! what at your old tricks?

SP.SPEAKER: ENN.
SP.P: I've an idea—it had been only one.

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: And you're delighted because it is an hour later.

SP.SPEAKER: ENN.
SP.P: To be sure I am my dear friend—to be sure I am—the enemy has lost a limb!

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: So you are happier because you're an hour nearer the other world! Tell me now do you wish to die?

SP.SPEAKER: ENN.
SP.P: No, but I wish somebody would invent a new mode of killing time—in fact, I think I've found one— private acting.

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: Acting! never talk to me about the stage —I detest the theatre and every thing that belongs to it —and if ever—but no matter—I must to Lady Waitfort and prevail on her to marry me, at the same time you marry my ward—but remember our agreement—you are to settle your estate on Louisa, and I am to bring you into parliament.

SP.SPEAKER: ENN.
SP.P: In fact I comprehend—I am to be a hearer and not a speaker.

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: Speaker? if you open your mouth the Chiltern Hundreds will be your portion—look'ye—you are to be led gently to the right side—to sleep during the debate—give a nod for your vote, and in every respect move like a mandarine at my command—in short you are to be a mandarine member, so farewel.

SP.SPEAKER: ENN.
SP.P: I've an idea, here's Neville! In fact he knows nothing of my marrying Louisa—nor shall he till after the happy day. Strange news Neville!

SP.SPEAKER: NEV.
SP.P: I've heard it all, Louisa' going to be married, and my lord persists in his fatal atrachment to Lady Wait∣fort.

SP.SPEAKER: ENN.
SP.P: In fact! why fatal!

SP.SPEAKER: NEV.
SP.P:
Because it is the source of every mischief—while she maintains her power over him, I have no hope of love or fortune—when my father died, he left his estate
to my brother relying on my lord providing for me, and now he deserts me and all owing to the artifices of an in∣siduous woman.

SP.SPEAKER: ENN.
SP.P: I've an idea, I comprehend her motive. She loves you!

SP.SPEAKER: NEV.
SP.P: Yes, 'tis too plain, and because I would not li∣sten to her advances, she has ruined me in my uncle's o∣pinion, and degraded me in Louisa's; but I will see Miss Courtney myself, I will hear my doom from her own mouth, and if the avoids me, I'll leave her and this country for ever.

SP.SPEAKER: PET.
SP.P: A letter sir.

SP.SPEAKER: NEV.
SP.P: Without a direction! What can it mean?

SP.SPEAKER: PET.
SP.P: Sir, 'tis from Lady Waitfort, the servant who brought it said her ladyship had reasons for not directing it, which she would explain to you when she saw you.

SP.SPEAKER: NEV.
SP.P: Oh the old stratagem, as it is not directed she may swear it was designed for another person, (reads) “Sir, I have heard of your arrival at Bath, and strange as my conduct may appear, I think it a duty I owe the virtuous part of mankind to promote their happi∣ness as much as I can, I have long beheld your merit and long wish'd to encourage it, I shall be at home at six this evening—Your's ”A. WAITFORT.

SP.SPEAKER: ENN.
SP.P: In fact a very sentimental assignation, that wou'd as well do for any other man.

SP.SPEAKER: NEV.
SP.P: If I shew it to my lord, I know his bigotry is such that he wou'd (as usual) only suppose it a trick of my own, the more cause there is to condemn, the more he approves.

SP.SPEAKER: ENN.
SP.P: I've an idea he's incomprehensible—in fact who have we got here?

SP.SPEAKER: NEV.
SP.P: As I Eve, Vapid the dramatic author, he is come to Bath to pick up characters I suppose.

SP.SPEAKER: ENN.
SP.P: In fact—pick up!

SP.SPEAKER: NEV.
SP.P: Yes, he has the ardor seribendi upon him so strong, that he wou'd rather you'd ask him to write an Epilogue to a new play than offer him your whole estate. The theatre is his world, in which are included all his hopes and wishes, in short he is a dramatic maniac.

SP.SPEAKER: ENN.
SP.P: Has he not a share of vanity in his composition?

SP.SPEAKER: NV.
SP.P: Oh, yes, he fancies himself a great favourite with the women.

SP.SPEAKER: ENN.
SP.P: Then I've an idea, I've got a thought by which you may revenge yourself on Lady Waitfort—in fact—give him the letter—he'll certainly believe 'tis meant for himself.

SP.SPEAKER: NEV.
SP.P: My dear friend, a thousand thanks, we'll flatter his vanity by persuading him she's young and beautiful, and my life on't it does wonders—but hush, here he comes.

SP.SPEAKER: NEV.
SP.P: Vapid, I rejoice to see you! 'tis a long time since we met, give me leave to introduce you to a parti∣cular friend of mine—Mr Ennui—Mr Vapid!

SP.SPEAKER: ENN.
SP.P: I've an idea, you do me honour. Mr Vapid I shall be proud to be better acquainted with you—in fact, any thi new in the literary worl?

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Some whispers about a new pantomime, sir, no∣thing ci.

SP.SPEAKER: NEV.
SP.P: And I'm afraid in the present scarcity of good writers, we have little e to expect—pray Vapid how is the present eth of genius to be accounted for—par∣ticularly dramatic ges?

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Why as to dramatic genius, sir, the fact is this, to give a true picture of life, a man should enter into all its ; should follow nature sir, but modern authors plunder from one another, the more shade of shadows; nw ir, for my part I dive into the world, I search deep into the heart of man, 'tis true I'm call'd a rake, but u∣pon my soul, I only game, drink and intrigue, that I may be beer able to dramatize each particular scene.

SP.SPEAKER: NEV.
SP.P: A good excuse for prolig ey—but tell me Va∣pid, have you got any new character since you came to Bih?

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Faith—only two—and these not very new either.

SP.SPEAKER: ENN.
SP.P: —may we what they are?

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: If

SP.SPEAKER: NEV.
SP.P: We do

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P:
you—he first is a charitable di∣vie. consideration he shall la∣vish his at all—and the other is
a cautious apothecary who in determining which of two medicines is best for his patient, lets him die for want of assistance—you understand me, I think the last will do something, Eh?

SP.SPEAKER: ENN.
SP.P: I've an idea—the apothecary would cut a good figure in a comedy.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: A comedy! psha! I mean him for a tragedy.

SP.SPEAKER: ENN.
SP.P: In fact I don't comprehend, nor possibly the town.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Now that's the very thing—hark'ye, I've found out a secret—what every body understands, nobody ap∣proves, and people always applaud most where they least comprehend—there is a refinement fir, in appearing to understand things incomprehensible—else whence arises the pleasure at an Opera, a private Play, or a Speech in Parliament? Why 'tis the mystery in all these things—'tis the desire to sind out what nobody else can—to be thought wiser than others—therefore you take me, the Apothecary is the here of my tragedy.

SP.SPEAKER: NEV.
SP.P: Faith there is some reason in all this, and I'm amazd we have so many writers for the Stage.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: So am I— and I think I'll write no more for an ungrateful public—you don't know any body that has a Plav coming out do you?

SP.SPEAKER: NEV.
SP.P: No, why do you ask?

SP.SPEAKER: VAP
SP.P: He'll want an Epilogue you know that's all.

SP.SPEAKER: NEV.
SP.P: You won't write one, will you?

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: I! oh lord! no, I won't write one; but genius you know ought to be encouraged, and as he's a friend of your's—what's the name of the play?

SP.SPEAKER: NEV.
SP.P: I really don't know any body has written one.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Yes, yes, you do you queer dog.

SP.SPEAKER: NEV.
SP.P: Upon my word I do not—a cousin of mine in∣deed wrote one for his own amusement, but I don't think he could ever be prevail'd on to produce it on the stage.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: He prevail'd o!—The Manager you mean could it be prevail'd on—but what do you think of it?

SP.SPEAKER: NEV.
SP.P: I never read it, but I'm told it is a good play—and if perform'd, Vapid, he will be proud of your .

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: I speak in time, because it is material—many a dul play has been saved by a good Epilgue.

SP.SPEAKER: NEV.
SP.P: True, but I had almost forgot—why Vapid, the lady in the grove will enlarge your knowledge amazingly.

SP.SPEAKER: ENN.
SP.P: I've an idea—she's the pattern of perfection.

SP.SPEAKER: NEV.
SP.P: The paragon of beauty! Ah Vapid! I would give worlds for the coldest expression in this letter.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: That letter!—What do you mean by that letter?

SP.SPEAKER: NEV.
SP.P: And you really pretend not to know the young Lady Waitfort!

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: No,—I hav'nt spoke to a woman since I came to Bath, except a sweet girl I danc'd with at the Ball; and who she is by the Lord I don't know.

SP.SPEAKER: NEV.
SP.P: Well but Vapid—young Lady Waitfort, she loves you to distraction!

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: As I hope for fame—I never heard her name before.

SP.SPEAKER: NEV.
SP.P: Then she has heard your's and admires your genius—however read the letter and be satisfied she loves you.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP. (Reads)
SP.P: "Your arrival at Bth—Duty I owe the virtuous part of mankind long beheld your merit—long wished to reward—at home at six this evening—your's—A. Waitfort—grove."—Yes, yes, 'tis plain e∣nough now—she admires my talents—it is'nt the first time Neville, this has happen'd—Sweet fond creature!— I'll go and prepare myself directly.

SP.SPEAKER: NEV.
SP.P: Ay, do Vapid,—She'll be all on fire to see you.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: All on fire! I suppose so, so shall I, and then there will be a general blow up—write a play Neville, write a play you dog—you see the effect of the muses and graces when they unite—you see Neville, you see—but hold, hold! how the devil came you by this letter?

SP.SPEAKER: NEV.
SP.P: That's true enough. (Ase.) I'll tell you, I was at her party last night, and on coming out of the room she lipt it in my hnd, desired me to direct it and give you—she has often spoke to me in your favour, and I did you all the good I could—however to be sure it's no mistake, ask the servant wh amits you, if the name at the to, is not her own hand writing

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Oh no! it's no miake, there's no doubt of the matter—write a play Neville, write a play, then you'll learn like me to exerte the pastons—but I must go to her directly, .

SP.SPEAKER: ENN.
SP.P: I've an idea—if we've common fortune this will do every thing.

SP.SPEAKER: NEV.
SP.P: No, Lady Waitfort's arts are numberless—she is so perfect a hypocrite, that I even doubt her confessing her real sentiments, to her minior. Willoughby; and when she does a bad action, she never pretends 'tis from a good motive.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: 'Gad, I forgot—you'll recollect the Epilogue Neville!

SP.SPEAKER: NEV.
SP.P: Yes, yes, I'll write to my cousin to-day.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: But not a word of the love affair to him — any where else indeed it might do one a service—but never tell an intrigue to a dramatic Author.

SP.SPEAKER: ENN.
SP.P: In fact—why not sir?

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Because it may furnish out a seene for a Come∣dy, I do it myself indeed, I think the best part of our in∣trigue is the hopes of incident or stage effect—however I can't stay.

SP.SPEAKER: NEV.
SP.P: Nay, we'll walk with you—I'm in pursuit of my brother—you of your mistress.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP
SP.P: Ay Neville, there it is—now do take my advice and write a play—if any accidents happen, remember it is better to have written a da'd play than no play at all—it snaches a man from obscurity, and being parti∣cular (as this world goes) is a very great thing.

SP.SPEAKER: NEV.
SP.P: P I confess I have no desire to get into print.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Get into print! psha!—that has nothing to do with it—every body gets into print now—kings and quack,—peers and poets—bishops and boxers—taylors and trading justices—one can't go lower you know—all get into print!—but we sar a little higher—we hve privges peculiar to ourselves.—Now sir, I—for y part n talk as I please say what I will, it to excite mirth, for supposing you don't laugh at say wit, damme. I laugh myself, Neville, and that makes every body else the same—to alls!

SP.SPEAKER: ENN.
SP.P: I've an idea—no bad mode of routing the ene∣my.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE—A Chamber in Lady WAITFORT'S House.

SP.SPEAKER: SERVANT.
SP.P: SIR, my lady will wait on you immediately.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Hark'ye sir, is this young lady of yours hand∣some!

SP.SPEAKER: SERV.
SP.P: Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Is your young lady, sir, very handsome?

SP.SPEAKER: SERV.
SP.P: Yes sir, my young mistress is thought a perfect beauty.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Oh charming!—what age do you reckon her!

SP.SPEAKER: SERV.
SP.P: About twenty, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: That's the right interesting age!—and fond of the Drama I suppose?

SP.SPEAKER: SERV.
SP.P: Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Very fond of plays I presume!

SP.SPEAKER: SERV.
SP.P: Yes sir, very fond of plays or any thing relating to them.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Delightful!—now am I the happiest dog alive! Yes, yes, Vapid, let the town damn your plays, the wo∣men will never desert you. (Seats himself on a chair.) You needn't stay sir. (Exit Serv.) That's a good sign, that fellow is'nt used to this kind of business—so much the better—practice is the destruction of love—yes, now I shall indulge a beautiful woman,—gratify myself, and perhaps get the last scene for my unfinished Comedy—lucky dog!

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: Sir your most obedient.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Ma'm

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: Pray keep your seat sir—I beg I mayn't disturb you.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: By no means ma'am—give me leave (hands a Chair, they both sit) who the devil have we got here. (aside.)

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: I'm told, sir, you have business for Lady Waitfort.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP
SP.P: Yes ma'am, but I could wait whole hours for so beautiful a woman!

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: Oh sir!

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Yes ma'am, I am no stranger to her charms! sweet young creature!

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: Nay! dear sir not so very young.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Your pardon ma'am, and her youth enhances her other merits—but oh! she has one charm that surpasses all!

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: Has she sir, pray what may it be?

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Her passion for the stage ma'am!

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Yes, her passion for the stage that in my mind, makes her the first of her sex.

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: Lord sir! she has no passion for the stage.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Yes, she has!

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: But I protest she has not.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: But I declare and affirm it as a fact, she has a strong passion for the stage, and a violent attachment for every body belonging to it.

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: Sir, I don't understand you—explain.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Hark'e we are alone—promise it shall go no fur∣ther, and I'll let you into a secret—I know.

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: Well sir—what do you know?

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: I know a certain dramatic author with whom she intrigues—he had a letter from her this morning.

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: What!

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Yes, an assignation—don't be alarm'd—the man may be depended on—it is safe—very safe—long in the habit of intrigue—a good person too—a very good per∣son.

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: Amazement!

SP.SPEAKER: VAP. (Whispering her)
SP.P: Hark'ye, he means to make her happy in less than half an hour.

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT. (Rising)
SP.P: Sir, do you know who you are talking to? do you know who I am?

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: No—how the devil should

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: Then know, I am Lady Waitfort!

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: You lady Waitfort?

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: Yes sir, and the only Lady Waitfort.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Mercy on me!—here's incident!

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: Yes, and I am convinc'd, you were sent here by that traitor Neville—Speak, is he not your friend?

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Yes, ma'am, I know Mr Neville—here's equi∣voque!

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: This is some trick, some stratagem of his—he gave you the letter to perplex and embarrass me.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Gave the letter! 'Gad that's great—pray ma'am, give me leave to ask you one question—did you write to Mr Neville?

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: Yes, sir, to confess the truth I did—but from motives.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Stop, my dear ma'am stop—I have it—now let me be clear—first you send him a letter; it is not so? Yes—then he gives it to me—very well: then I come (supposing you only twenty) mighty well! then you turn out to be ninety—charming! then comes the embarrass∣ment; then the ecclircissement! Oh glorious! give me your hand you have atoned for every thing!

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: Oh! I owe all this to that villain Neville—I am not revengeful, but 'tis a weakness to endure such repeated provocation, and I'm convinced that the mind, that too frequently forgives bad actions, will at last for∣get good ones.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Bravo! bravo! it is the very best sentiment I ever heard—I'll take it down and blend it with the inci∣dent, and you shall be gratified one day or other with seeing the whole on the slage— (takes out his common-place book and writes) "The mind that too frequently forgives bad actions, will at last forget good ones."

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: This madman's folly, is not to be borne—if my lord too shou'd discover him here, the consequences might be dreadful, and the scheme of Ennui's play all une—Sir, I desire you'll quit my house immediately—Oh! I'll be reveng'd I'm determin'd.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P:
There's an exit—very well! I've got incident however—'saith I've noble talents—to extract gold from le has been the tl of numberless philosophers: but I extract it from a better metal, human frailty—Oh it's a
great thing to be a dramatic genius! a very great thing indeed?
SP.STAGE: (As he is going off Lord Scratch enters.)

SP.SPEAKER: VAP
SP.P: Sir, your most obedient!

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: Sir, your most devoted!

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Very warm Tragedy weather sir—but for my part I hate summer, and I'll tell you why—the Theatres are then shut up sir, and when I pass by their doors in an evening it makes me melancholy—I look upon them as the tombs of departed friends that were wont to in∣struct and delight me—I don't know how you feel—per∣haps you are not in my way.

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Perhaps you don't write for the stage—if you do there is a capital character in the house for a farce!

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: Why what is all this? who are you?

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Whom am I!—Here's a question? In these times who can tell who he is? for ought I know, I may be great uncle to yourself, or first cousin to Lady Waitfort— to the very woman I was about to—but no matter, since you're so very inquisitive, do you know who you are?

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: Who am I—why I'm Lord Scratch!

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: A Peer! contemptible! when I ask a man who he is, do you think I want to know what are his titles and such stuff—no, Old Scratch, I want to know what he has written, when he had the curtain up, and whether he's a true son of the Drama—hark'ye, don't make yourself uneasy on my account—in my next Pantomime perhaps I'll let you know who I am, Old Scratch!

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: Astonishing! can this be Lady Waitfort's House?—"Very warm tragedy weather sir, in my next pantomime let you know who I am,"—"gad I'll go and investigate the matter immediately, and if she has wrong'd me, by the blood of the Scratches, I'll bring the whole business before Parliament, make a speech ten hours long, reduce the price of opium, and set the nation in a tumult.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Either this house is a labyrinth, or I in reflecting on my incident have forgot myself; for so it is, I can't find my way out—Eh! who have we here?—by the sixtieth night, my little partner!

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: The poet I danced with!—he little thinks how much I've thought of him since? Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Ma'am,

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: I hope sir, you caught no cold the other night.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: No, ma'am, I was much nearer a fever than a cold—pray ma'am what is your study?

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: I have been reading "All for Love"—pray sir do you know any thing about plays?

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Know any thing about plays! there's a question.

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: I know so much about them, that I once acted at a private Theatre.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Then you acted for your own amusement and nobody's else: what was the play?

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: I can't tell.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Can't tell.

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: No—nobody knew—it's a way they have.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Then they act no play of mine—so, then with all this partiality for the stage—perhaps you wou'd be content with a dramatist for life? particularly if his morals were fine.

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: Lord! I don't care about fine morals, I'de ra∣ther my husband had fine teeth—and I'm told most wo∣men of fashion are of the same opinion.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: To be sure they are—but cou'd you really con∣sent to run away with a poet?

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: 'Faith with all my heart—they never have any money you know, and as I have none, our distress wou'd be compleat, and if we had any luck our adventures wou'd become public, and then we shou'd get into a Novel at last.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Into a prison more porbably—if she goes on in this way, I must dramatize her first, and run away with her afterwards (aside) come are you ready?

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT. (without.)
SP.P: Tell my lord I'll wait in the Library.

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: Oh Lord! my aunt, what's to be done!

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: What's to be done! why?

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: She mustn't find you here—she'll be the death of me she's so violent.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Well, I'm not afraid of her—she's no critic.

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: No, but if you've any pity for me—here hide yourself for a moment behind this sopha, and I'll get her out of the room directly.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Behind this sopha! here's a new situation!
SP.STAGE: (gets behind the Sopha, Marianne sits on it, takes out her working bag, and sings.

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: Toll de roll, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: Marianne, how came you here? I desire you'll leave the room directly!

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: Leave the room aunt?

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: Yes, leave the room immediately—what are you looking at?

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: Nothing aunt, nothing—Lord, lord! what will become of poor Mr Poet.

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: So, here's my lord—now to mention En∣nui's play, and if it does but prejudice him against him, Willoughby marries Louisa, and Neville is in my own power.

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: That curst pantomime ruffian—nobody knows any thing about him—perhaps my lady has got a sudden touch of the Dramatic Maniac, and prefers him— here she is, now if she shou'd talk about the stage.

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: Pray be seated my lord—I want to ask you a favour.

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: Ask me a savour! is it possible my lady?

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: Yes, for our friend Ennui—what do you think he has done?

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: What!

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: Turn'd author—he has written a comedy.

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: A comedy! She has it!

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: Yes, 'tis very true, and it has been appro∣ved of by men of the first dramatic fame!

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: Dramatic fame! She has it, damn me but she has it.

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: Nay, if you need further proof my lord, it has been approv'd by the manager of one of the theatres, and the curtain is to be drawn up next winter.

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P:
The curtain drawn up! Look'ye ma'am, I care no more for the manager, or his theatre, or his
prompter—
SP.STAGE: (Vapid raises his head from behind the Sopha, then pops it down.)

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: Now my lord, the favour I have to ask of you is this. Promise me to peruse the play, make alte∣rations, and wrie the Epilogue.

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: Write the Epilogue! Fire and fore fa∣thers!

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: Ay, or the Prologue!

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: The Prologue! Blood and gunpowder!
SP.STAGE: (Vapid jumps up from behind the Sopha, and smacks Lord Scratch on the back.)

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Prologue or Epilogue! I am the man—I'll write you both.

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: There he is again!

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: Oh I shall faint with vexation, my lord I beg you'll misinterpret nothing—every thing shall be ex∣plain'd to you. Marianne!

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: Here's the curtain up with a vengeance.

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: Answer me directly, how came that gentle∣man in this apartment? I know it is some trick of yours.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP. (coming down the stage.)
SP.P: To be sure never was a∣ny thing so fortunate! Upon my soul I beg your pardon; but curse me if I can help laughing to think how lucky it was for you both I happened to be behind the sopha, ha. ha. ha.

SP.SPEAKER: MAR. (As if taking the hint.)
SP.P: Faith no more can I—To be sure it was the luckiest thing in the world ha, ha, ha.
SP.STAGE: (ere they oth laugh and point to Lord Scratch and La∣dy Waitsort, who look amaz'd.)

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: Sir, I insist you'll lay aside this levity, and instantly explain how you came into this house!

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Sir—Ha, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: Ay, sir—explain—and dispatch—I in∣treat you dispatch—I have so much to say—

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Never fear old lady—I'll take care of you,

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: None of your whispering—speak out sir!

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: With all my heart—then I came here, sir, by her Ladyship's own appointment.

SP.SPEAKER: L WAIT.
SP.P: My own appointment! I shall run wild!

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: To be sure—you have hardly forgot your own hand writing—

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: Her own hand writing! Get on sir—I beseech you get on.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Why look'ye Old Scratch—you seem to be an admirer of this lady's—now I think it my duty as a moral Dramatist—mark me, sir, a moral Dramatist, to expose hypocrisy—therefore, sir, there is the letter, read it and be convinced of your error.

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: Very well! Have you, done sir? have you done? consider I am a Peer of the Realm, and shall die if I don't talk.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: And now sir, I must beg a savour of you, (gets close to him)—keep the whole a secret, for if it gets hack∣nied it loses all its force.

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: Granted! granted—I'll grant you any thing so you will but get on.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Between ourselves—I mean—

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: No pauses sir.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: To bring it all on the stage! hush! say nothing—it will have a capital effect, and brother Bards will wonder where I stole it—Your situation will be wonder∣ful—you havn't an idea how ridiculous you'll look—you'll laugh very much at yourself I assure you, your part shall be done well! little Cherry shall do you!

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: What is all this?—well—now I will speak—I'll wait no longer.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Yes, yes, I'll take care of you—Falstaff in the Buck basket will be nothing to it—he was only the dupe of another man's wife, but you'll be the dupe of your own you know—"think of that Master Brook, think of that,"—well I'll write you the Prologue and Epilogue; but you need not send me the Comedy, we never connect either with the play now—your friend may be damn'd you know and don't chuse to suffer for his sins—I like to live and sight another day—Marianne farewell my dear—Old Lady adieu—I'll do your business depend on't.

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P:
He's gone without hearing me! then there's an end of every thing, for now here I stand—once a Barrister—since a Country Gentleman, and now a Peer, and tho' I've made twenty attempts to speak, I
can't be heard a syllable—Mercy, mercy! What will the world come to! a Peer and not to be heard!

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: My Lord, assured of my own innocence, I have no doubt of justifying myself, and even by means of that letter encreasing your affection—it was written to another person—your ungrateful nephew.

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: My nephew!

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT
SP.P: Yes sir, I cou'd not perceive him losing the esteem of his friends without having the desire to reclaim him—indeed I knew no better mode of fulfilling my pro∣ject, than by personally warning him of his situation—for this purpose I wrote that letter, and I never thought it would be thus misus'd—if there is any improper warmth in the expressions it only proceeds from my anxiety of ensuring an interview—I hope sir, you are satisfied?

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: Why I believe you my lady, and I shou'd be perfectly satisfied if I cou'd forget your passion for the stage, and that madman behind the sopha.

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: As to that sir, this young lady can inform you I desired him to leave the house an hour ago.

SP.SPEAKER: MAR. (Aside.)
SP.P: I'm afraid, my only way is to confess all—my lord, if I confess the truth, I hope you'll pre∣vail on my aunt to forgive me.

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: Tell what you know, and I'll answer for your forgiveness.

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: Why sir, I found the gentleman alone, and not having had a tete-a-tete a long time, I press'd him to stay, and on hearing your voice, I put him behind the sopha—that you might not think any thing had happen∣ed—and indeed sir, nothing did happen—upon my word he's as quiet an inoffensive gentleman as yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: My fears are over! Oh you finished com∣position! come to my arms, (embraces) and when I sus∣pect you again (coughs much) this curst cough takes one so suddenly!—

SP.SPEAKER: ENN.
SP.P: I've an idea, Florivelle is arrived, in fact I just now spoke to him.

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P:
Florivelle arrived! Come my lady, let's go and we what his travels have done for him—hark'ye Ennui—prepare for your interview with Louisa, and re∣member
you make a mandarine member—come my la∣dy—nay, never irritate your feelings.

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: Alas my lord! it is the misfortnne of vir∣tue to be too feeling for the vices and errors of others—but I attend you.

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: So poor Mr Neville is to lose Miss Courtney—her present quarrel with him is so violent, that she may marry this ideot merely in revenge. If I could dupe him now and ensure her contempt. I'll try—Mr Ennui, have you seen your intended wife yet?

SP.SPEAKER: ENN.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: So I thought—why you'll never please her while you remain as you are—you must alter your man∣ners. She's all life—all spirits! and loves a man the very opposite to you.

SP.SPEAKER: ENN.
SP.P: I've an idea, I'm very sorry—in fact how can I please her?

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: There's the difficulty, let me see—the sort of man she likes—you know Sir Harry Hustle—a man all activity and confidence—who does every thing from fashion and glories in confessing it.

SP.SPEAKER: ENN.
SP.P: Sir Harry Hustle! In fact he's a modern blood of fashion.

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: I know that's the reason she likes him, and you must becme the same if you wish to win her affections—a new dress, bold looks, a few oaths and much swag∣gering effects the business (Ennui puts himself in attitudes) ay, that's right, you are the very man already!

SP.SPEAKER: ENN.
SP.P: I'm a lad of fashion! hah—damn me! I've an idea, I shall fall asleep in the midst of it.

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: No, no, go about it directly—See Sir Harry Hustle, and study your conversation before-hand—but re∣member Louisa is so sond of fashion, that you can't boast too much of its vices and absurdities.

SP.SPEAKER: ENN.
SP.P: If virtue was the fashion, I shou'd be virtuous! I shou'd, damn me!

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: Ay, that's the very thing—well good b'ye Mr Emmi—succes attend you—mind you talk enough.

SP.SPEAKER: ENN.
SP.P: Talk! I'll talk till I fall asleep! ill, damn me!

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE—A Chamber in Lady WAITFORT'S House.—LOUISA discovered reading.

SP.SPEAKER: LOUISA.
SP.P: HEIGHO! these poets are wonderfully tiresome—always on the same theme—nothing but love—I'm weary of it. (Lays down the book and rises.) Ungenerous Neville! How cou'd he use me so cruelly? to attempt to gain my affections and then address another. Lady Waitfort has convinc'd me of the fact, I can never for∣give him, and yet I fear I love him still. Well, I'll e∣ven go and examine my heart and determine whether I love him or not.
SP.STAGE: (As she is going out Neville enters.)

SP.SPEAKER: LOU.
SP.P: Mr Neville—I thought sir, I had desired we might never meet again.

SP.SPEAKER: NEV.
SP.P: 'Tis true madam, and I meant to obey your commands hard as they were, implicitly obey them—but I came here to welcome my brother, and not to in∣trude on the happiness of her I am doom'd to avoid.

SP.SPEAKER: LOU.
SP.P: I'll conceal my embariassment, I am determin'd. (Aside.) If I remember, sir, truth was ever among the foremost of your virtues.

SP.SPEAKER: NEV.
SP.P: , and I am confident you have no reason to doubt it—tho' you have cause to censure my presump∣tion, you have none to suspect my fidelity.

SP.SPEAKER: LOU.
SP.P: Oh no! I don't suspect your fidelity in the least, but when peple are faithful to more than one, you know, Mr Neville.—

SP.SPEAKER: NEV.
SP.P: I n't understand you ma'am.

SP.SPEAKER: LOU.
SP.P: 'Tis no wonder Mr Nevie—you may spare yurself any uble in attempting to justify your conduct—I'm perfectly satisfied sir, I'll assre you!

SP.SPEAKER: NEV.
SP.P: Oh! do not leave me in this anxious state, per∣haps this is he last time we shall ever meet; and to part thus wou'd embier every future moment of my life. I indeed have no hopes that concern not your happiness, no wishes that relate not to your esteem.

SP.SPEAKER: LOU.
SP.P: Sir, I will freely confess to you, had you shewn the least perseverance in your affection, or sincerity in your behaviour, I cou'd have heard your addresses with pleasure—but to listen to them now Mr Neville, wou'd be to approve a conduct my honour prompts me to re∣sent, and my pride to despise.

SP.SPEAKER: NEV.
SP.P: Then I am lost indeed! 'tis to the perfidious Lady Waitfort I owe all this— (Lady Waitfort enters behind unseen by Neville)—my present misery, my future pain are all the product of her jealous rage! she is so vile an hypocrite that

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: Who is an hypocrite, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: NEV.
SP.P: Madam!

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: Who is a hypocrite sir, answer me?

SP.SPEAKER: NEV.
SP.P: What have you done? look on that lady, ma∣dam, there all my hopes and wishes were combin'd! there was the very summit of my bliss! I thought I had attained it; but in the moment of my happiness you came, crush'd every hope and bassted all my joys!

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: Upon my word sir, very romantic—but I thank heaven I look for approbation in a better opinion than that of Mr Neville's.

SP.SPEAKER: NEV.
SP.P: 'Tis well you do madam, for were I your judge, your punishment shou'd be exmplary—but I'll waste no more words on you—I only hope (to Louisa) you ma∣dam are satisfied that one of my errors may at leat be forgiven, and this last suspicion or ever blotted from your memory.

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: But I'll take care my lord never shall.

SP.SPEAKER: N. v.
SP.P: No— I do not hope for forgiveness— I have heard her determination, and cruel at i to that I must re∣sign— she may be assured I never with intrude where I know I offend.

SP.SPEAKER: LOU.
SP.P: Do you then leave us Mr Neville?

SP.SPEAKER: NV.
SP.P: Yes, madam, and for ever! —may you be as blest in the gratification of your hopes as I have been wrtched in the disappointment of mine.

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: Tyrant! I wish he had stay'd to hear rea∣son—I hope he is not seriu in leaving us!

SP.SPEAKER: LOU
SP.P: You hope! —why does it concern yu?

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P:
Oh! no further than from the general love
I bear mankind—you forget my feelings on these occasi∣ons, Louisa!

SP.SPEAKER: LOU.
SP.P: Yes, indeed I have too much reason to attend my own!—You'll excuse me—I have particular business, but will return immediately.

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: Oh, the cause of her confusion is evident—she loves him still—but they shall never meet again—I have already sent a letter to Willoughby, which imparts a scheme I have long cherished, my lord in his anger about my sage maniac, has forgot Ennui's play, so that there may be no bars to Willoughby's happiness, I am determined Louisa shall be this very night.

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: Here's a spectacle for a Peer! Florivelle is below, and is reurn'd from his travels a finished cox∣comb, I'll not give him a farthing.

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: I hope not my lord, perhaps you may be mistaken.

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: Mistaken! No, he has travell'd not to see, but to say he had been seen.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter MARIANNE (with a French watch and chain.)

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: Oh uncle-in-law! look here—I never saw any so elegant in all my life.

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: Whose present is this?

SP.SPEAKER: MAR. Whose!
SP.P: why the sweet gentleman just arri∣ved from Italy—Lord! he's a dear man—he has pro∣mis'd to do every thing for me—to get me a fortune—to get me a husband—to get me—a—

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: Hush!—you don't know what you are talking about.

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: Yes, but I do tho', he has told me every thing—Lord! I have heard such things! — come hear—nearer—get my aunt out of the room and I'll tell you stories that shall make your old heart bound again!—hush do it qui∣etly—I will upon my honour—what an old fool it is.

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: You mustn't listen to Mr Florivelle, for tra∣vellers may persuade you into any thing, and many a woman has been ruin'd in one country, by being told it is the fashion in another.

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: Here he comes—I see as plain as my peerage I shan't keep my temper.

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: I suppose my lord he has spent great part of his time in France, where he has been the dupe of knaves of every nation.

SP.SPEAKER: FLOR.
SP.P: Your pardon madam, you wrong the French—they never suffer any one to dupe a traveller but them∣selves—ladies a thousand pardons for not waiting on you before; but this is the first vacant moment I have had since my arrival at Bath.

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: Your coming at all is taken as a very great compliment I'll assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT. (To Marianne who exits.)
SP.P: — Leave the room immediately—no reply — I will be obey'd—Mr Florivelle, we are very happy to see you.

SP.SPEAKER: FLOR.
SP.P: Ma'am you do me honour—my lord where's Harry? I thought to have found him here—what, he didn't chuse to stay—so much the better—it shews he's not a man of ceremony—we do the same in Italy—but hark'ye.

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: My gorge is rising! I shall certainly do him a mischief.

SP.SPEAKER: FLOR. (Spying at Lady Waitfort)
SP.P: Rather experienc'd or so—a little antique hah!—however, the same motive.

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: Sir, from that lady's forgiveness you have nothing to expect—If she consents to pardon you, that which makes her a good aunt to me, will make her a good wife to you—you understand me.

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: Damn me if I do!

SP.SPEAKER: FLOR.
SP.P: Well, well, no matter—come come, I want to hear every thing, to know what remarkable occurrences have happen'd since I left England—pray Lady Wait∣fort inform me—do let me know every little circumstance.

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: Rather sir, we should ask of you, what hap∣pen'd in your travels?

SP.SPEAKER: FLOR.
SP.P: Oh nothing so shocking—no man can be the herald of his own praise!

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: Yes, sir, but I wish to know how you like the chapel of Loretto, the Venus de Medicis of Florence, the Natican at Rome, and all the numberless curiosities peculiar to the countries you have travell'd.

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P:
Look'ye—I'll answer for it, he knows
nothing of the gentlemen you mention—do you my sweet pretty—oh you damn'd puppy!

SP.SPEAKER: FLOR.
SP.P: But why swear my lord?

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: Swear my lord! zounds! its my pre∣rogative and by—tell me how you spent your time, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: FLOR.
SP.P: Why in contemplating living angels, not dead antiquities! in basking in the rays of beauty! not moul∣dering in the dust of ancestry! in mirth, festivity and pleasure! not study, pedantry, and retirement—oh I have lived sir! lived for myself, not an ungrateful world, who, shou'd I die a martyr for their cause, wou'd only laugh and wonder at my folly.

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: You seem to know the world Mr Florivelle.

SP.SPEAKER: FLOR.
SP.P: No madam, I know little of mankind, and less of myself—I have no pilot but my pleasures! no mistress but my passions! and I don't believe if it were to save my life I cou'd reason consequently for a minute toge∣ther.

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: Granted—you have seen every thing worth seeing, yet know nothing worth knowing, and af∣ter all you have just knowledge enough to prove yourself a fool on every subject.

SP.SPEAKER: FLOR.
SP.P: Vastly well my lord, upon my word you im∣prove with your title; but I am perfectly satisfied believe me; for what I don't know, I take for granted is not worth knowing—therefore we'll call another topic, I'm in love my lord!

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: In love!—with who sir?

SP.SPEAKER: FLOR.
SP.P: Can't you guess?

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: No sir, I cannot!

SP.SPEAKER: FLOR.
SP.P: With one that will please you very much—at least ought to please you—you'll be in raptures dear un∣cle!

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: Raptures;—and you shall be in agonies my dear nephew!

SP.SPEAKER: FLOR.
SP.P: You have known one another a long while, yet you hav'nt met for years—you have lov'd one another a long while, yet you quarrel'd not an hour ago, you have differ'd from one another all your lives, yet are likely to be friends as long as you live, and above all, this person is now in this house.

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCATCH.
SP.P: In this house! tell me who it is this mo∣ment, or by the blood of the Scratches!

SP.SPEAKER: FLOR.
SP.P: One who has charms enough to set the world on fire! one who has fortune enough to set a state at war sir! one who has talents, health and prosperity, and yet not half what the party deserves—can you tell now sir?

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: No, sir, and if you don't tell this instant.

SP.SPEAKER: FROR.
SP.P: Then I'll tell you. Its myself, sir—my own charming self!—I've search'd the world over, and don't find any thing I like half so well.

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: I won't disgrace myself—I won't lower the dignity of peerage by chastising a commoner, else you prince of butterflies—come my lady—look'ye sir—I intend to be handed down to posterity; and while you are lampoon'd in ballads and news-papers, I mean to cut a figure in the history of England—so come along my lady—in the history of England! you damn'd cox∣comb.

SP.SPEAKER: FLOR.
SP.P: If the face be a picture of the mind, that in∣tended aunt of mine is a great hypocrite, and the story I heard of the poet proves it—but now for a frolic—'gad its very strange I cou'd never reform and become a seri∣ous thinking being! but what's the use of thinking?

Q.L: "Reason stays till we call, then not oft is near,

SP.SPEAKER: WILL.
SP.P: Tell your mistress I shall be punctual to the appointment. (Exit Servant.) So thanks to fortune, Lady Waitfort has at last consented to my entreaties, and this night makes Louisa mine for ever!—now to read the letter once more— (Reads) Louisa accompa∣nies “me to night to Lady Walton's, which you know is at the extremity of the town—on some presence or other, I'll tell her I have order'd the servant at the back gate, which adjoins the paddock—there I'll leave her, and if you have a chaise waiting near the spot you may conduct her where you please, you know my feelings on this occasion, but it is for her good only I'll assure you—she don't deserve it Mr Willoughby:—Indeed ”she don't deserve it. A. Waitfort!

So! this is beyond my hopes—Ha! my lord! and Louisa with him! come to receive Ennui, whom to my as∣tonishment I met just now in a new dress, swearing and capering, and boasting of the vices of fashion, but no matter—I must to the rendezvous immediately. Now Louisa, tremble at my vengeance.

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: Yes, yes, Ennui will be here in an in∣stant, but he's so reserv'd, and so mild.

SP.SPEAKER: LOU.
SP.P: So I understand sir, and so very silent that he won't talk so much in a year as I intend in an hour.

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: I know that's the reason I bring him in∣to Parliament—he'll never speak—only say aye, or no, and be up stairs to Beef stakes in an instant. (Knock.) Here he is?—now encourage him Louisa, don't mind his diffidence.

SP.SPEAKER: LOU.
SP.P: No sir,—I'll do all in my power to make him talk.

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: That's well,—I'll leave you together—I don't interrupt you. (Stamping without) odso, I must get out of the way—encourage him Louisa, I beseech you encourage him.

SP.SPEAKER: ENN. (without)
SP.P: Stand by no ceremony, damn me.

SP.SPEAKER: LOU.
SP.P: Heavens! is this diffidence!

SP.SPEAKER: ENN.
SP.P: Get down stairs you dog—get down— (Exit Servant)—Here I am ma'am—ease is every thing—I'll feat myself—now for business,—Yaw, yaw.

SP.SPEAKER: LOU.
SP.P: Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: ENN.
SP.P: In one word ma'am, I'll tell you my character—I'm a lad of fashion dam'me, I love gaming, I hate thinking—I like railing—I despise reading—I patronize boxing—I detest reasoning—I pay debts of honour—not honourable debts.—In short I'll kick your servant—cheat your family, and fight your guardian—and so if you like me take—heh, damn me—I'm tired already—yaw—yaw?—yawns.

SP.SPEAKER: LOU.
SP.P: Astonishing! Mr Ennui.

SP.SPEAKER: ENN.
SP.P: Ma'am, yaw—yaw—

SP.SPEAKER: LOU.
SP.P: Mr Ennui! Can you be in your senses?

SP.SPEAKER: ENN.
SP.P:
In fact I don't comprehend, (forgetting himself)
Oh! ay—senses (recollecting himself,)—a lad of fashion in his senses! that's a very good joke—if one of us had any sense, the rest would shut him up in a cabinet of cu∣riosities, or shew him for a wonderful animal! they wou'd damn me; I can't support it—yaw—yaw.

SP.SPEAKER: LOU.
SP.P: So you glory in your ignorance—

SP.SPEAKER: ENN.
SP.P: Ma'am, yaw—yaw!—

SP.SPEAKER: LOU.
SP.P: So you glory in your ignorance—in your vices.

SP.SPEAKER: ENN.
SP.P: I've an idea—I can't understand (forgetting him∣self) vices—Oh—ay damn me to be sure! (recollecting himself) You must be wicked or you can't be visited—singularity is every thing—notoriety—every man must get a character—and I'll tell you how I first got mine. I pretended to intrigue with my friend's wife—para∣graph'd myself in the newspapers—got caricatured in the print shops—made the story believed, was abused by every body—noticed for my gallantry by every body, and at length visited by every body—I was, damn me! (I'm curst sleepy) yaw, yaw.

SP.SPEAKER: LOU.
SP.P: Incredible! but if singularity be your system, perhaps being virtuous wou'd make you as particular as any thing

SP.SPEAKER: ENN.
SP.P: Vastly well! Egad you're like me—a wit and don't know it (takes out his watch) how goes the enemy? more than half the day over! tol de rol lol, (singing) I am as happy as if I was at a fire, or a general riot—Come to my arms thou angel! thou— (as he is going to embrace her, enter LORD SCRATCH who catches him.) Ah Scratch! my friend Scratch! sit down my old boy, sit down, we've fettled every thing

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: Why! what is all this?

SP.SPEAKER: ENN.
SP.P: She's to intrigue—and you and I are to go halves in the damages—some rich old Nabob—we'll draw him into crim con! bring an action directly—and get a 10,000 l. verdict at least, heh! damn me!

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: Why he's mad. That dramatic Mani∣ac has bit him.

SP.SPEAKER: ENN.
SP.P: Get a divorce—marry another, and go halves again damn me!

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P:
Why look'ye, you impostor you, didn't you come here to pay your addresses to this lady—and
wasn't I to bring you into parliament for your quiet, si∣lent disposition?

SP.SPEAKER: ENN. (Pushing him out of the way.)
SP.P: Hold your tongue! out of the way Scratch, out of the way! or I'll do you a mischief damn me! Zounds! ai'nt I at the top of the beau monde? and don't I lead the fashion? If I was to cut off my head wou'dnt half the town do the same, they wou'd damn me. I get sleepy again, yaw—yaw.

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: Here now, here's a mandarine member, why he'd breed a civil war! make ten long speeches in a day! Cut your head off indeed! Curse me but I wish it was cut off—you must be silent then—you can't talk without a head cou'd you?

SP.SPEAKER: ENN.
SP.P: Yes, in parliament, as well without a head as with one—do you think a man wants a head to make a long speech damn me?

SP.SPEAKER: SERV.
SP.P: Her ladyship is waiting ma'am.

SP.SPEAKER: LOU.
SP.P: Oh: I attend her, Mr Ennui, your most obedi∣ent.

SP.SPEAKER: ENN. (Taking her hand.)
SP.P: With your leave ma'am, you see Scratch—

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: Why Louisa!

SP.SPEAKER: ENN.
SP.P: Keep your distance Scratch—contemplate your superirs—look at me with the same awful respect as city beaus look at a prince—this way most angelico—Scratch, cut off your head—this way most divine angelico.

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: Here's treatment! Was ever a poor peer so tormented—what am I to do? I'll go to Lady Wait∣fort, for from her alone I meet relief—find a silent mem∣ber indeed! by my peerage and privilege one might as soon find a pin in the ocean, as charity in a bench of Bi∣shops, or wit in Westminster Hall.

SP.SPEAKER: WILLOUGHBY.
SP.P: 'TIS past the hour Lady Waitfort appointed—Why does she delay? I cannot have mistaken the place—yonder is Lady Walton's house! Oh would all were past, and Louisa safely mine: I hear a noise! by Hea∣ven's 'tis she, and with her all my happiness—I'll with∣draw a while and observe them.

SP.SPEAKER: LOU.
SP.P: My dear Lady Waitfort, why do you loiter here? You cannot find your servant in this place, let us return to Lady Walton's.

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: No, no, they must be here, I order'd them to wait in this very spot to avoid confusion.—What can have become of Willoughby?

SP.SPEAKER: LOU.
SP.P: If you have the least sense of fear for yourself, or regard for me, I beg we may return to Lady Walton's.

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: No, no, I order'd William at the back gate that he might conduct us through the paddock to our carriage, you know we might have been whole hours getting thro' the crowd the other way, do be a little pa∣tient, hav'nt I as much reason to be alarm'd as yourself?

SP.SPEAKER: LOU.
SP.P: Yes, but you hav'nt the apprehension that I have, I don't know why, but I am terrified beyond description!

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: Well, well, never fear, (looking out) Oh, yonder's Willoughby! now for the grand design! (aside) if you'll stay here a moment, I'll step to the next gate and see if they are there—they cannot escape us then.

SP.SPEAKER: LOU.
SP.P: No, no! don't leave me! I wouldn't stay by myself for the world!

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P:
Ridiculous! can't you protect yourself for an instant? Must you be all your life watched like a baby in leading strings? Oh! I'm asham'd of you, only wait
a moment, lest they pass by in my absence, and I'll re∣turn to you immediately.

SP.SPEAKER: LOU.
SP.P: Well don't stay!

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: Stay! What have you to be frightened at? I shall not be out of call, besides if there's any ear of a personal attack, may not I be as terrified as yourself. It is'nt the first time I'll assure you—but that's no mat∣ter, shew yourself a woman of spirit, and at least emu∣late one of my virtues—now Willoughby the rest is thine

SP.SPEAKER: WILL.
SP.P: Be not alarm'd Miss Courtney!

SP.SPEAKER: LOU.
SP.P: Mr Willoughby!

SP.SPEAKER: WILL.
SP.P: Yes madam, the man you most avoid.

SP.SPEAKER: LOU.
SP.P: Tell me sir immediately how, and by whose ap∣pointment you came here?

SP.SPEAKER: WILL.
SP.P: By love madam, the same passion that has prompted me to pursue you for years, now happily con∣ducts me hither—I come to lessen your fears, not to en∣crease them.

SP.SPEAKER: LOU.
SP.P: Then leave me sir, I can protect myself.

SP.SPEAKER: WILL.
SP.P: No, not till you have heard and pitied me—I have been long your suitor, and long scorn'd by you—you have treated me with indifference, and preferr'd my inferiors—how I have deserv'd all this, yourself can best explain; but to prove all former cruelties are forgot, I here offer you my hand and with it my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: LOU.
SP.P: Sir, this is no time for hearing you on this sub∣ject, it you wish to oblige me, leave me.

SP.SPEAKER: WILL.
SP.P: No, not till I am answer'd—years may elapse e're I shall have another opportunity like the present, therefore no time can be so well as now.

SP.SPEAKER: LOU.
SP.P: Then, I command you to leave me, I will not be threatened into a compliance.

SP.SPEAKER: WILL.
SP.P: Look'ye, Miss Courtney, I wou'd avoid taking advantage of your situation—nay start not—but if you persist in your contempt of me, I know not to what extre∣mities passion may hurry me, I have every motive for redress, a df you do not instantly give me your word to prefer me to that beggar Neville, I may do that my cooler sense would scorn.

SP.SPEAKER: LOU.
SP.P: Beggar sir!

SP.SPEAKER: WILL.
SP.P: Yes, and were he not beneath my resentment, I'd tell you more—but he's too poor—too—

SP.SPEAKER: LOU.
SP.P: Hold sir, did you resemble him, I might esteem, nay adore you; you take advantage of my situation; hear me sir! tho' not a friend is near, tho' night oppo∣ses me, and Heaven deserts me, yet can I smile upon your menaces, for my own eyes shall vindicate my wrongs, and make you tremble villain, as you are!

SP.SPEAKER: WILL.
SP.P: Have a care madam, another declaration like that, and I'll delay no longer, I'll force you to my pur∣pose.

SP.SPEAKER: LOU.
SP.P: You dare not, on your life you dare not.

SP.SPEAKER: WILL.
SP.P: Nay, then, I'm not to be terrified by threats— (lays hold of her) all struggling is in vain, this moment gratifies my revenge! away.

SP.SPEAKER: LOU.
SP.P: Off—let me go, Oh help! help!
SP.STAGE: (As he is for∣cing her out, enters FLORIVELLE half drunk.)

SP.SPEAKER: FLOR. (Singing part of an Italian Song.)
SP.P: Donne, don∣ne, don—Oh this burgundy's a glorious liquor—hey day! who have we here?

SP.SPEAKER: LOU.
SP.P: Oh sir, if you have any pity for an injur'd help∣less woman, assist one who never knew distress till now.

SP.SPEAKER: FLOR.
SP.P: Go on ma'am, go on! both damned drunk I perceive.

SP.SPEAKER: LOU.
SP.P: Do not sir be deaf to my intreaties, do not de∣sert me.

SP.SPEAKER: FLOR.
SP.P: Go on madam, go on—I love oratory in a wo∣man!

SP.SPEAKER: LOU.
SP.P: Gracious Heaven! how have I deserved this? I see sir you avoid me—I see you're indifferent to my fate.

SP.SPEAKER: FLOR.
SP.P: No ma'am, you wrong me—but in Italy ob∣serve we always take these things coolly—now sir (to Willoughby) will you explain.

SP.SPEAKER: WILL.
SP.P: No sir, I will not.

SP.SPEAKER: FLOR.
SP.P: You will not.

SP.SPEAKER: WILL.
SP.P: No sir, and I warn you not to listen to the wild ravings of a senseless woman—it may be better for you sir.

SP.SPEAKER: FLOR.
SP.P: Why so, Prince Prettyman?

SP.SPEAKER: WILL.
SP.P: No matter sir, I will not be amused from my purpose.

SP.SPEAKER: FLOR.
SP.P: You won't old Pluto, won't you! then ma'am observe, you shall behold my mode of fighting—I'll kill him like a gentleman, and he shall die without a groan —you'll be delighted ma'am—I learn't it all in Italy— you don't see a man of fashion fight once in a century! Come Beelzebub are you ready?

SP.SPEAKER: WILL.
SP.P: 'Sdeath what can I do? he is drunk perhaps, I may disarm him.

SP.SPEAKER: FLOR.
SP.P: Now thou original sin! Thou Prince of Dark∣ness! come out, never let her see thy black infernal vi∣sage more, or by my life I'll pulverise you! You see ma'am no bad orator either—learnt it all in Italy.

SP.SPEAKER: WILL.
SP.P: Come on sir.

SP.SPEAKER: FLOR.
SP.P: Ay now old Sysippus push home—but do you hear, fight like a gentleman, for remember there's a la∣dy in company. Observe ma'am, observe! you won't see it again! (They fight, Florivelle disarms him). What vanquish'd Tarquin! Hah! (parrying up and down the stage in triumph.) You see ma'am, you fee—Oh Italy's your own country! Now madam, wou'd you have me kill him here "en allegro," or postpone it, that you may have the pleasure of pinking him yourself "en penseroro."

SP.SPEAKER: LOU.
SP.P: Florivelle my deliverer! Generous man! No, sir, whatever are his crimes do not kill him—his greatest pu∣nishment will be to live.

SP.SPEAKER: FLOR.
SP.P: There then Caitiff, take your sword, and d'ye hear—retire—that black face of thine offends the lady— if you want another flourish you will soon find Florivelle —Abscond!

SP.SPEAKER: WILL.
SP.P: Sir, you shall soon hear from me—Distraction!

SP.SPEAKER: FLOR.
SP.P: And now my dear little angel! how can I as∣sist you? I'm very sorry but I cannot help it—I'm curst drunk and not proper company for a lady of your dignity—but I won't affront you, I mean to make my∣self agreeable, and if I do not it is the fault of this place (pointing to his head) and not this (pointing to his heart.)

SP.SPEAKER: LOU.
SP.P:
Sir, your conduct has endear'd you to me for
ever, and while I live, your generosity and valour shall be engraven on my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: FLOR.
SP.P: Gently, gently, have a care, make no declara∣rations —if you are in love with me, as I suppose you are, keep it a secret, for at this moment you might raise a flame that wou'd consume us both, poor creature! how fond she is of me, any other time I wou'd indulge her, but not now (looks at her, and then runs and kisses her hand.) Oh you paragon! "Angels must paint to look as fair as you," (goes from her again) I'll leave you, or by Heavens! it will be all over with us.

SP.SPEAKER: LOU.
SP.P: No, no, don't desert me, alas I have no way left, but to commit myself to your care. If I cou'd bring him to recollect me all wou'd be safe—Mr Flori∣velle, don't you know me?

SP.SPEAKER: FLOR.
SP.P: No—would to Heaven I did.

SP.SPEAKER: LOU.
SP.P: What, not Miss Courtney?

SP.SPEAKER: FLOR.
SP.P: What Louisa! my brother's idol?

SP.SPEAKER: LOU.
SP.P: The very same.

SP.SPEAKER: FLOR.
SP.P: Then may I die, if I don't get out of your debt before I leave you—where, where shall I conduct you?

SP.SPEAKER: LOU.
SP.P: Alas! I know not—return to Lady Waitfort's I will not, I had rather be a wanderer all my life—to Lady Walton's there is no excuse for my returning. I know no friend in Bath I dare intrude upon—I have so high an opinion Mr Florivelle of your honour, that not∣withstanding your present situation, there is no man on earth I wou'd sooner confide in, can you then think of any place where I may rest in safety for a few hours; and then I will set out for my uncle's in the country.

SP.SPEAKER: FLOR.
SP.P: Indeed I cannot, I am a wanderer myself—I have no house, but what this gentleman is to purchase me (taking out his purse) You cannot partake of that.

SP.SPEAKER: LOU.
SP.P: Oh what will become of me?

SP.SPEAKER: FLOR.
SP.P: Let me see—I have it—I'll take her to my bro∣ther's —she'll be safe there and not a soul shall come near her—well Miss Courtney, I have recollected a place where I know you'll be safe—a friend's house that will be as se∣cure —nay, don't droop, in Italy never, never melancholy!

SP.SPEAKER: LOU.
SP.P:
Oh, Mr Florivelle! to what a hazard has Lady
Waitfort expos'd me—to her perfidy I owe it all—but yonder's that wretch again, pray let us begone.

SP.SPEAKER: FLOR.
SP.P: Beelzebub again? no, no—mustn't stir—what an angel fly from a devil! I'll stay and crush him, Tar∣quin avaunt! come my best angel! I'll fight your bat∣tles, and if I don't sink all your enemies, may I never see Italy again as long as I live.

SP.SPEAKER: WILL.
SP.P: Ha! gone! I'm sorry for it—I wou'd have seen them, Lady Waitfort has just left me and treated me like her slave—insulted and derided me—but I'll have done with her for ever—I'll be her dupe no more—She is now gone to Neville's lodgings under pretence of pursuing Louisa; but in fact to see him, and prevent his leaving Bath; thus I hope I shall make some reparations for the wrongs I have committed, and prove at least that I have some virtue.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE—NEVILLE'S Lodgings.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Well, here it is—where's Neville?

SP.SPEAKER: PET.
SP.P: Not within sir.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Yes, yes, here it is—I must see him.

SP.SPEAKER: PET.
SP.P: Sir he's gone out.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Gone out! impossible!

SP.SPEAKER: PET.
SP.P: Impossible! it's very true sir.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Gone out! why I have brought him the epilogue —the new epilogue to Mr What's his name's comedy— the very best thing I ever wrote in my life—I knew it wou'd delight him.

SP.SPEAKER: PET.
SP.P: Sir, he has been gone out above these two hours.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Then he'll never forgive himself as long as he lives—why its all correct—all chaste! only one half line wanting at the end to make it compleat.

SP.SPEAKER: PET.
SP.P: Indeed sir, its very unfortunate.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Unfortunate! I wanted to have heard him read it too, when another person reads it, one often hits on a thought that might have otherwise escaped, then per∣haps he wou'd have hit on that curs'd half line I've so long been working at.

SP.SPEAKER: PET.
SP.P: Sir, if it is not impertinent, and you'd permit me to read it—

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: You read it!

SP.SPEAKER: PET.
SP.P: Yes, sir, if you'd allow me the honour.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Eh! Why faith I wou'd have no objection— but then wou'dn't it lessen one's dignity! no, no, Moliere used to read his plays to his servant—so I believe all's regular—but sir, can you read! come then begin.
SP.STAGE:
Peter reads the Epilogue.
"In ancient times when agonising wars,
"And bleeding nations fill'd the world with jars,
"When murder, battle, sudden death prevail'd
"When!—

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P:
Stop, stop! I have it—not a word for your life —I feel it—its coming on! the last line directly—quick, quick— Peter reads,
"The tyrant totters and the senate nods,
"Die all, die nobly— here's something wanting sir.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P:
I know it, say nothing—I have it (walking up and down the stage.)
"The tyrant totters and the senate nods,
"Die all, die nobly!— Oh damn it! damn it! damn it! that curs'd half line— I shall never accomplish it—all so chaste—all so correct— and to have it marr'd for wanting one half line! one curst half line! vexatious! I cou'd almost weep for dis∣appointment.

SP.SPEAKER: PET.
SP.P: Never mind it sir, don't perplex yourself, put in any thing.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Put in any thing! why you damned dog what do you mean—put in any thing, why you raseal, 'tis the last line, and the pilogue must end with something stri∣king or it will be no trap for the galleries, no trap for applause after all this sine writing! Oh, 'tis too much!—

SP.SPEAKER: PET.
SP.P: Methinks this is a strange Epilogue for a Co∣medy. Perhaps this is my master sir, no as I live, 'tis Mr Florivelle and Miss Courtney▪ She mustn't on any account be seen by this gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Well, who is it?

SP.SPEAKER: PET.
SP.P: Sir it's a friend of my master's who has brought a lady with him—I'm sure you've too much gallantry to interrupt an amour, and therefore you'll be kind enough to get out of the way directly.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Get out of the way? What the devil in the mid∣dle of my composition?

SP.SPEAKER: PET.
SP.P: Nay sir, only step for a moment into that closet, and you shall soon be releas'd—now pray sir, be pre∣vail'd on.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Well, let me see, in this closet! why you damn'd dog! this is a china closet! wou'd you ram a live author into a china closet?

SP.SPEAKER: PET.
SP.P: What can I do sir, there is no other way out but that door—do sir, get in here, for an instant, and I'll shew them into the library—now sir—

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Well, be brief then—"Die all—die nobly!" Oh, Oh, Oh!

SP.SPEAKER: FLOR.
SP.P: Hey day! my old acquaintance Peter! where's my brother?

SP.SPEAKER: PER.
SP.P: Sir, he has been out the whole evening.

SP.SPEAKER: LOU.
SP.P: In the same house with Neville, Oh Heavens!

SP.SPEAKER: FLOR.
SP.P: Well now Miss Courtney I hope you're con∣vinc'd of your safety?

SP.SPEAKER: LOU.
SP.P: Yes, sir, but I wou'd it were in any other place: Lady Waitfort e're this is in pursuit of me, and if she discovers me here, you know too well how much I have to dread.

SP.SPEAKER: FLOR.
SP.P: Don't be alarm'd, there's nothing shall molest you.

SP.SPEAKER: LOU.
SP.P: Oh, sir! you don't know the endless malice of Lady Waitfort—she will triumph in my misery, and, till my lord is convinc'd of her duplicity, I see no hopes of your brother's happiness or my own.

SP.SPEAKER: PET.
SP.P: Lady Waitfort is below sir, enquiring for that lady, or my master.

SP.SPEAKER: FLOR.
SP.P: For my brother?

SP.SPEAKER: PET.
SP.P: Yes, sir, and my lord has sent to know if her ladyship or Mr Vapid has been here. He was in bed, but on receiving a letter, got up, and will be here in an instant.

SP.SPEAKER: LOU.
SP.P: For Heaven's sake Mr Florivelle, let me retire I cannot support the conflict.

SP.SPEAKER: FLOR.
SP.P: Prom to recal your spirits and you shall.

SP.SPEAKER: LOU.
SP.P: What I can do I will.

SP.SPEAKER: FLOR.
SP.P: Then know no apprehensions, for on my life you shall not be disturb'd.

STAGE.HI: (Leads her to the door of the library and talks in dumb shew.)

SP.SPEAKER: VAP, (from the closet)
SP.P: Peter, Peter, can't you release me?

SP.SPEAKER: PET.
SP.P: No, sir, don't move, you'll ruin every thing.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Then give me that candle — I've got a pen and ink, and I think I can finish my Epilogue.

SP.SPEAKER: PET.
SP.P: Here sir,

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: That curst half line, "Die all—die nobly!"

SP.SPEAKER: FLOR. (sits at table and drinks)
SP.P: So now the storm be∣gins, and I'll have some sport with the enemy—here she comes.

DIV3.STAGE: Chairs Peter—chairs! sit down Ma'am, you honour ma exceedingly.

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: Where's your brother sir, I insist on seeing him.

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: There she is, in a man's lodgings at midnight! here's treatment?

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: My lord I came here in search of Louisa, who has been betray'd from my power.

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRARCH.
SP.P: Look'ye my lady read that letter, and then say if we shan't both cut a figure in the print shops.

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT. (taking the letter.)
SP.P: Ha! 'tis Willougby's hand! reads, "Lady Waitfort, I have only time to tell you, is gone to Neville's lodgings, to meet a person she has long had a passion for, follow her and be convinced of her duplicity." Oh the villain! Well my lord, and pray who is the man I came to meet?

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: Why who shou'd it be but the stage ruffian, if there was a sopha in the room, my word on't he'd pop from behind it—Zounds that fellow will lay straw at my door every nine months.

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P:
This is fortunate [aside] well, sir, if I dis∣cover Louisa, I hope you'll be convinced I came here to
redeem her—and not disgrace myself. Tell me sir, im∣mediately, where she's conceal'd.

SP.SPEAKER: FLOR.
SP.P: Sit down ma'am, sit down—drink—drink, then we'll talk over the whole affair—there is no doing busi∣ness without wine—come "here's the glory of gallantry" I'm sure you'll both drink that.

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: No trifling sir,—tell me where she is con∣cealed—nay then I'll examine the apartments myself— (goes to the door of the library) the door lock'd, give me the key, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: FLOR. (drinking.)
SP.P: The glory of gallantry!

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: Hear me sir, if the lady is in that apart∣ment, I shall be convinc'd that you and your brother are the sole authors of all this treachery—if she is there—by the honour of my ancestors she shall be Willoughby's wife to-morrow morning.

SP.SPEAKER: FLOR. (Rising)
SP.P: Shall she my Lord! pray were you ever in Italy?

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRAICH.
SP.P: Why? Coxcomb?

SP.SPEAKER: FLOR.
SP.P: Because I'm afraid you have been bitten by a tarantula—you'll excuse me but the symptoms are won∣derfully alarming! there is a blazing fury in your eye, a wild emotion in your countenance, and a green spot on your nose.

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: Damn the green spot! open that door immediately—I am a Peer, and have a right to look at every thing.

SP.SPEAKER: FLOR. (standing before the door.)
SP.P: No sir, this door must not be open'd.

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: Then I'll forget my peerage and draw my sword

SP.SPEAKER: FLOR (To Lady Waitfort who is going to interfere,)
