SP.P: don't be alarm'd ma'am—I'll indulge him for my own amusement—mere trout fishing to me ma'am—come my lord, I'll give you a specimen of foreign gladiatorship, and you shall confess that Forivelle is the best fencer in Europe, don't be alarm'd ma'am, come on.

SP.SPEAKER: LOU.
SP.P: ! I charge you hold, let not my unhappy fate be the source of more calamities.

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: 'Tis she herself! my lady did not come to meet the madman!

SP.SPEAKER: FLOR.
SP.P: By the lord, ma'am, you've ruin'd all.

SP.SPEAKER: LOU.
SP.P: I know, sir, the consequences of this discovery and I abide by them—but what I have done I can justi∣fy, and would to heaven all here could do the same.

SP.SPEAKER: FLOR.
SP.P: Indeed I can't tell—I wish I was in Italy.

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: Mark me madam, nay tears are in vain, to-morrow shall make you the wife of Willoughby, and he shall answer for your follies—no reply—sir, (to Flo∣rivelle, who is going to speak) I wou'dnt hear the lord Chancellor.

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: Now who is to blame? Oh virtue is ever sure to meet its reward! come to meet a mad poet in∣deed! my Lord, I forgive you only on condition of your signing a contract to marry me to-morrow, and Louisa and Willoughby at the same time.

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: I will thou best of women!—draw it up immediately, and Neville shall starve for his treachery
SP.STAGE: (Lady Waitsort goes to the table and writes.)

SP.SPEAKER: LOU. (falling at Lord Scratch's feet.)
SP.P: Hear me sir, not for myself but a wrong'd friend I speak—Mr Neville knows not of my concealment, on my honour; he is in∣nocent. If that lady's wrongs be aveng'd, confine the punishment to me—I'll bear it; with patience bear it.

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: Let go—let go I say! my gorge is ri∣sing again—Lady Waitfort make haste with the contract.

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: It only wants the signature—now my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: FLOR.
SP.P: Look'ye my Lord!—she is the cause of all this mischief, and if you are not lost—

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: Out of my way—noise and nonsense!— don't fancy yourself in the House of Commons—We're not speaking twenty at a time, here give me the pen— I'll sign directly, and now—
SP.STAGE: (As be is going to sign, Vapid breaks china in the closet, and rushes out with the Epilogue in his hand.(

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Die all! die nobly! die like demi Gods—Huz∣za, huzza, 'tis past, 'tis done! 'tis perfect.

STAGE.HI: (Jumps a∣bout the stage with extravagant tokens of joy.)

SP.SPEAKER: FLOR.
SP.P: Huzza! the mad poet at last, stop him, who can.

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: Confusion! tell me sir immediately, what do you mean by this new insult?

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P:
Die all! die nobly!—die like demi Gods!—Oh 'tis glorious!—ah, old Scratch are you there! Joy, joy!
give me joy! I've done your business, the work's past, the labour's o'er my boy—think of that master Brook, think of that.

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: My Lord, I'm vilely treated, I desire you'll insist on an explanation.

SP.SPEAKER: FLOR.
SP.P: He can't speak ma'am,

STAGE.HI: (all this time past my Lord is slowly walking away.)

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: How!—are you going to leave me my lord?

SP.SPEAKER: VAP. Taking out his common-place book.
SP.P: Faith this mustn't be lost—here's something worth observing.

SP.SPEAKER: FROR.
SP.P: Don't stop him, ma'am—in every furrow of his angry brow is written "frailty, thy name is woman" —let him have his way.—See how solemnly he re∣tires.

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: Oh, I shall burst with rage! Mr Vapid, I desire you'll explain how you came into that closet? why don't you answer me, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Your pardon ma'am, I am taking a note of the whole affair—and yet I'm afraid.

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: What are you afraid of, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: That it has been dramatiz'd before—it is cer∣tainly not a new case.

SP.SPEAKER: L WAIT.
SP.P: Insupportable! but I take my leave of you all—I abandon you for ever—I—oh! I shall go wild.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Exit in a rage.

SP.SPEAKER: FLOR.
SP.P: Ay follow his Lordship, "virtue is ever sure to meet its reward."—Now, Mr Vapid, pray tell us how you came into that closet?

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Upon my soul I can't—I believe the servant hur∣ried me in on your approach.

SP.SPEAKER: FLOR.
SP.P: Then you didn't come to meet Lady Waitfort?

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: I come to meet Lady Waitfort!—no, I came to read my Epilogue to Neville, and a wonderful production it is—I'll read it to you—"The tyrant totters, and the senate nods"

SP.SPEAKER: LOU.
SP.P: To what a strange fatality of circumstances has her character been exposed! but vice often finds its pu∣nishment for a crime never committed, when it escapes for thousands it daily practises.

SP.SPEAKER: FLOR.
SP.P: Well Miss Courtney, I hope your apprehensions are all at an end.

SP.SPEAKER: LOU.
SP.P: Yes, sir; I shall remain for the short time ne∣cessary to prepare for my journey—and beg I may detain you no longer—I'm afraid I have already been a great intruder.

SP.SPEAKER: FLOR.
SP.P: No—you have been the occasion of more hap∣piness than ever I experienc'd, but you won't leave Bath till you have seen my brother.

SP.SPEAKER: LOU.
SP.P: Oh! I have been cruelly deceived Mr Flori∣velle, I have injured your brother so much, that tho' I wish, I almost dread to see him.

SP.SPEAKER: FLOR.
SP.P: Then I'll go in search of him, and if I don't reconcile you—come Mr Vapid, will you walk?

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: With all my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: FLOR. (Taking Vapid by the hand.)
SP.P: By heaven an ho∣nest fellow, and if all poets were like you, I'd become one myself—Miss Courtney adieu, expect me to return.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Madam, good night, if I can be of any service in the dramatic, or any other way, you may command me.

SP.SPEAKER: FLOR.
SP.P: Ay, I'll answer for him, he would die to serve you.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Die to serve her!—ay—die all! die nobly! die like demi Gods.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE—An apartment at Lady WAITFORT'S.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady WAITFORT.
SP.P: MR Vapid not come yet Letty?

SP.SPEAKER: LETTY.
SP.P: No madam—but the servant who found him at the tavern, said he would be here immediately.

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: I protest I'm almost weary of them all— See who's there?

SP.SPEAKER: LETTY.
SP.P: Mr Vapid at last, now pray your ladyship, in∣sist on his explaining every thing to my lord.

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: Yes; but vilely as he has treated me, I must still be calm.

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: Walk in sir, walk in.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: No ma'am—I'd rather stay here.

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: I beg you'll walk in Mr Vapid.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP. Enters gently.
SP.P: — Pray be seated sir, I have something of consequence to impart to you.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: I'd never have ventured, but in hopes of seeing my dear Marianne.

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: Indeed, I will not detain you a moment.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Very well ma'am, if that's the case, slowly seating himself its very alarming!

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: Letty, leave the room and fasten the door.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: No, no, turning to Letty, don't fasten the door, I beseech you.

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: You're very much frightened, Mr Vapid! I hope you don't think I've any designs against you.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: I don't know really ma'am, such things are per∣fectly dramatic

SP.SPEAKER: L WAIT.
SP.P: Well, but I release you from your fears, I'll tell you why I have given you this trouble—my bu∣siness, Mr Vapid, was to converse with you on the farci∣cal affair that happen'd at Neville's.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Farcical!

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: Yes, sir, the farcical affair that happen'd at Mr Neville's.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Farcical! what my Epilogue, ma'am! I hope you don't mean to reflect on that.

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: No, sir, far from it—I have no doubt but it is a very elegant composition.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Doubt! here it is—read it—the very first pro∣duction of the age—a regular climax of poetic beauty —the last line the ne plus ultra of genius.

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: But to be serious, Mr Vapid.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Why I am serious—and I'll tell you Lady Wait∣fort —'Tis the last line of an Epilogue, and the last scene of a comedy that always distracts me—'tis the reconcilia∣tion of lovers—there's the difficulty!—you find it so in real life I dare say?

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: Yes, but Mr Vapid, this affair concerns me exceedingly, and I wish to know what is to be done?

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P:
I'll tell you—write a play, and bad as it may pos∣sibly be, and I dare say 'twill be bad enough, yet say 'tis a translation from the French, and interweave a few
compliments on the English, and my life on't it does wonders—do it, and say you had the thought from me.

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: Sir, do you mean to insult me?

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: But only be cautious in your style,—women are in general apt to indulge that warm luxuriancy of fancy they possess—but do be careful—be decent—if you are not, I've done with you.

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: Sir, I desire you'll be more respectful—I don't understand it at all

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Then here comes one that will explain every thing.

LG.L: "There's in her all that we believe of Heav'n,

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: My dear Marianne, my sweet little partner, I rejoice to see you.

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: And my dear sweet Mr Poet, I rejoice to see you.

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: Provoking! hav'n't I told you a thousand times not to break in upon me when I am alone.

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: Alone! My lady, do you reckon Mr Vapid no∣body them.

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: Suppose I shou'd, what is it to you?

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: Then I have no notion of your nobodies—I al∣ways thought them harmless unmeaning things—but Mr Vapid's not so very harmless either—are you Mr Vapid?

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Indeed ma'am, I am not.

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: There now I told you so—upon my word you rely too much on your time of life—you do indeed—you think because you're a little the worse for wear, you may trust yourself any where—but you're mistaken—you're not near so bad as you imagine—nay, nay I don't flatter, do I Mr Vapid?

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Indeed ma'am you do not.

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: Look'ye Miss—your insolence is not to be borne—you have been the chief cause of all my perplexity.

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: Nay aunt, don't say that.

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: No matter, your behaviour is shameful, and it is high time I exert the authority of a relation—you are a disgrace to me—to yourself and your friends— therefore I'm determin'd to put into execution a scheme I have long thought of.

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: What is it? something pleasing I hope.

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: No, but you shall retire to a convent, till you take possession of your fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: A convent! Oh Lord! I can't make up my mind to it, now don't, pray don't think of it—I declare its quite shocking.

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: It is a far better place than you deserve— my resolution is fix'd, and we shall see whether a life of solitude and austerity, will not awaken some sense of shame in you.

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: Indeed I can't bear the thoughts of it—Oh do speak to her Mr Vapid, tell her about the nasty monks, now do—A convent! mercy! what a check to the passions? Oh! I can't bear it.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: 'Gad here's a sudden touch of tragedy—pray Lady Waitfort, reflect, you can't send a lady to a con∣vent while the theatres are open—see it will break the poor girl's heart—Don't weep so Marianne.

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: I can't help it—it will be the death of me— pray my dear aunt—

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: Not a word—I'm determin'd—to morrow you shall leave this country, and then I have done with you for ever.

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: Oh, my poor heart!

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: See, she'll faint!

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: Oh, oh!

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: Oh! I have gone too far, what's to be done?

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Some relief immediately, or she'll expire— where shall I fly, I'll call the servants.

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: No, 'twill be too late—I have some drops in the next closet may recover her—hold her a moment, and for heaven's sake take care of her.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Poor girl! how I pity her! I really loved her.

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: Did you really love me, Mr Vapid?

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Hey day recovered! here's incident!

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: But did you really love me, Mr Vapid?

SP.SPEAKER: VAP
SP.P: Yes, I did—what stage effect!

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: And wou'd you have really run away with me Mr Vapid?

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Yes, I really wou'd—a new situation!

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: Then come along this moment.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Hush! here's the old lady! keep dying as be∣fore, and we'll effect the business—more equivoque!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Wait.
SP.P: Well Mr Vapid, how does she do now? Lord! She's in strong convulsions!

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Yes, ma'am, she's dying! where are the drops?

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: Here sir.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: There are very few—are there any more of the same kind?

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: Yes sir, plenty.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Fetch them—'tis the only hope—if you have any hartshorn too, bring a little of that—our feelings will need it all.

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: Very true Mr Vapid—I declare to you I'm quite shock'd!

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: Well, Mr Vapid—now let's run away—come —why what are you thinking of?

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: My last scene—and I fear—

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: What do you fear?

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: That it can't be managed—let me see—we cer∣tainly run away, and she returns—faith I must see her return.

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: No, no, pray let us be gone, think of this ano∣ther time.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: So I will, it will do for the fourth tho' not for the fifth act—therefore my dear little girl come away, and we'll live and die together!

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: Die together.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Ay, die all! die nobly! die like demi gods!

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Lady WAITFORT (with two large smelling bottles.)

SP.SPEAKER: L. WAIT.
SP.P: Here Mr Vapid, here's the drops—What gone, mercy on me!—but no matter I wrong myself to think of her, I'll follow my lord, and if he still avoids me, I'll have done with them all for ever—ruin'd by a time-killer!—by a writer of Epilogues!—Oh! I shall burst with disappointment.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE—An apartment in Neville's House.

SP.SPEAKER: LOU.
SP.P:
Still in the fame house, yet still afraid to meet him—Oh Neville! my superior in every thing! how
can I hope for your forgiveness? While you revealed an affection it had done you credit to deny, I concealed a passion I might have been proud to confess.

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: Oh, Miss Courtney, my sweet Miss Courtney! Mr Vapid has run away with me, and I'm so frighten'd for fear of Lady Waitfort.

SP.SPEAKER: LOU.
SP.P: Yes, she may well alarm you—she has destroy'd my peace for ever! but have you seen Mr Neville? Yet why do I ask?

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Seen Mr Neville! What, doesn't he yet know you are in his lodgings?

SP.SPEAKER: LOU.
SP.P: No, and I hope never will, the moment his bro∣ther returns, I shall set out for my uncle's, and perhaps never see him more.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: And why not see him Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: LOU.
SP.P: Because I cannot bear the fight of one I have so injured

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: This will do, this will do—mutual equivoque! equal misunderstanding! my own case exactly.

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: Your own case Mr Vapid! Lord you base man! have you got a young lady in your longings.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Ridiculous!—don't talk about your ladies, at such an awful time—the very situation in my comedy!— the last scene to a syllable—here's an opportunity of im∣proving the denouement.

SP.SPEAKER: PET.
SP.P: Ma'am, my master is return'd—the occasion of his delay has been a long interview with Mr Willough by —he doesn't know you are here.

SP.SPEAKER: LOU.
SP.P: Marianne excuse me, you'll be safe from Lady Waitfort here—Indeed I'm very ill.

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: Nay, where are you going?

SP.SPEAKER: LOU.
SP.P: Alas! any where to avoid him.—Farewell! and may you enjoy that happiness I have for ever lost.

SP.SPEAKER: MAR
SP.P: Poor dear girl! I mustn't leave her thus.—Mr Vapid, we won't run away till something is done for her.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Go—there's a good girl—follow and comfort her.

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: I will. Lord, if they must be happy in being friends again, what must I be who make them so.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: The picture before me! all from nature. I must heighten his distress—for contrast is every thing. Peter, not a word for your life. Gives him a tap on the cheek. Not one word, you dull dog.

SP.SPEAKER: NEV.
SP.P: Vapid, I'm glad to see you! Any letter from my brother?

SP.SPEAKER: PET.
SP.P: No, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: NEV.
SP.P: Nor message?

SP.SPEAKER: PET.
SP.P: No, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: NEV.
SP.P: Then I need doubt no longer—'tis evident he avoids me. Cruel ungenerous Floriville.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP. [Leaning over his chair.]
SP.P: Miss Courtney will ne∣ver see you again!

SP.SPEAKER: NEV.
SP.P: I know it—too well I know it—that and that only makes me determine to leave this country for ever.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP
SP.P: You are unhappy then?

SP.SPEAKER: NEV.
SP.P: Completely so.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Then stop. [Sits by him.] She was a divinity, Harry!

SP.SPEAKER: NEV.
SP.P: An angel!

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: And thus to lose her!

SP.SPEAKER: NEV.
SP.P: S'death, don't torment me! [rising.] my griefs are already beyond bearing!

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: It will do—he's as unhappy as I could wish.

SP.SPEAKER: PET.
SP.P: I can hold no longer, sir—

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Hush, you damn'd dog! you'll ruin the catas∣trophe.

SP.SPEAKER: PET.
SP.P: I don't care—I'll tell him every thing—sir— Mr Neville.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP. Taking hold of Peter and leading him forward.]
SP.P: Hark'ye, you villain! do you ever go to a play? Do you ever sit in the gallery?

SP.SPEAKER: PET.
SP.P: Yes, sir, sometimes.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Then know this is all for your good—you'll ap∣plaud this some day or other, you dog. Curse it, won't he be happy enough by and by.—What, you are going abroad, Neville?

SP.SPEAKER: NEV.
SP.P: Yes, for ever—Farewell, Vapid.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Farewell, Neville! Good night. Now for the effect! Miss Courtney is in the next room.

SP.SPEAKER: NEV.
SP.P: What!

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Miss Courtney is in the next room.

SP.SPEAKER: NEV.
SP.P: Louisa! Is it possible?

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: There's light and shade.—Yes, your brother brought her here, and she expects him to return ev'ry moment.

SP.SPEAKER: NEV.
SP.P: My brother! Then 'tis he means to marry her—nay, perhaps they are already married.—Heavens! I shall go wild!

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Don't go wild—that will ruin the denouement.

SP.SPEAKER: NEV.
SP.P: No matter—I'm resolv'd, I'll bid her farewell for ever. Vapid, 'tis the last favour I shall ask of you, give her this letter, and tell her, since I have resented Willoughby's attack upon her honour, I think I may be allowed to vindicate my own, still great as have been my faults, my truth has still been greater, and wherever I wander—

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Here's a flourish now. Why you misunderstand—she is not married, nor going to be married.

SP.SPEAKER: NEV.
SP.P: Come, this is no time for raillery.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Raillery! Why I am serious—serious as the last act—Zounds! go to her, preserve the unity of the action; marry her directly, and if the catastrophe does not con∣clude with spirit, why damn my comedy—damn my comedy, that's all.

SP.SPEAKER: NEV.
SP.P: Would to heaven you were in earnest.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Earnest—why there it is now—the women, dear creatures, are alway's ready enough to produce effect; but the men are so curst undramatic—Go to her—I tell you go to her. Here is my lord and your brother with him. Come go to the lady—make as good an exit as you can. Two flourishes—that will do.

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: That curst dramatic maniac—if I see him again—

SP.SPEAKER: FLOR.
SP.P: My dear uncle, consent to Harry's marriage, and depend on't, he shall trouble you no more.

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: I tell you again, I will not.

SP.SPEAKER: FLOR.
SP.P: Will you give any hopes of future consent?

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: By the word of a Peer, I will not.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Master Brook, let me persuade you—

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: Flames and firebrands! the fiend again!

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Give your consent, and I'll give Neville a for∣tune—he shall have the entire profits of the different plays in which I intend to introduce yourself and the old Lady Hurlothrumbo.

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: Oh, that I was not a Peer! If I was any thing else, but thank heaven, Louisa is more averse to the match than myself.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Is she?

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: Yes, she knows his falsehold, and despises him.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: What, you are confident of it?

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: Out of my way, sir, I'll not answer you, I'll go take her to town directly.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Stop, master Brook—she's in that room.

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: Where, behind me?

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Yes, thee—there. (pointing.) Now for it—what an effect! Oh, charming!

DIV3.STAGE: Lord Scratch pens the door, and discovers Neville kneeling to Louisa, and Marrianne with them.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: There, Peter! there's a catastrophe! Shake∣spear's invention's nothing to it! applaud it, you dog—applaud it—clap, Peter, clap.

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: What are you at, you impudent rascal, get out of the room.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: I should set this down, I may forget.

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: He has a very bad memory—Lord, I hope he won't forget our marriage.

SP.SPEAKER: NEV.
SP.P: Oh, Louisa, what am I to think?

SP.SPEAKER: LOU.
SP.P: That I have wrongd thee Neville.

SP.SPEAKER: FLOR.
SP.P: My dear Harry, let this be my apology for not having seen you before (Gives a deed.) Miss Courney, ten thousand joys; and could I have found my brother, you should have seen him sooner.

SP.SPEAKER: NEV.
SP.P: Why, here is a deed of gift for half your estate.

SP.SPEAKER: FLOR.
SP.P: I know it, but say nothing; when you gav me money, five years ago, did I say any thing? No, I orgot it as soon as it was over, and should never have reccol∣lected it at this moment, but for my lord's inhumanity. Uncle, I thank you, you have made me the happiest man alive.

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: Don't perplex me, what a compound of folly and generosity.

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: Uncle-in-law, what are your feelings on this oc∣casion, as my aunt says.

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: Feelings! I never knew a Peer have any.

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: Didn't you.

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: No, but now I find the contrary; I be∣gin to think I've a heart like other men—it's better to a∣tone for an error than persist in one, therefore give me that deed, Neville. There sir, (giving it back to Flori∣velle) do you think nobody has estates to give away but yourself—Louisa and her fortune are your's Mr Neville, and after my death you shall have mine—and now there's a curst burden off my mind.

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: Now you're a dear creature! and I won't mar∣ry—that's what I won't without consulting you.

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: You marry! why shou'd you marry, and how came you here pray?

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: A gentleman run away with me, he is now in the room.

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: In the room! What Florivelle?

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: No behind you
SP.STAGE: (pointing to Vapid who is writing at the table.)

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: Ghost's and spectres! my evil genius!

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: Come my dear, haven't you almost finished?

SP.SPEAKER: VAP. (Rising)
SP.P: Yes, the denouement is compleat, and now my dear I resign myself to love and you.

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: Come, my good lord, pray give consent, my husband will get money tho' I have none.

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: None—I dare say he can tell you he will have twelve thousand pounds in less than a year.

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: Shall I? Then faith Mr Vapid, we'll build a theatre of our own—you shall write plays and I'll act them.

SP.SPEAKER: ENN.
SP.P: I've an idea I give you joy Mr Neville—I mean to kill time by living single and therefore I hope the lady and the borough may be yours.

SP.SPEAKER: MAR.
SP.P: Mr Ennui, I hope you'll pardon me and sir Harry Hustle the fatigue we occasioned you.

SP.SPEAKER: ENN.
SP.P: Don't mention it—yaw, yaw,—the very recol∣lection makes me faint—in fact my lord, I just met one of Lady Waitfort's servants who tells me she has left Bath in a rage.

SP.SPEAKER: FLOR.
SP.P: I'm afraid she has escaped too easily.

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: Oh, damn her! never think of her—I can answer for her punishment being adequate to her crimes—Willoughby has told me all her schemes, and if ever I hear her name again; may I lose my peerage and be forced to dress like a gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: ENN.
SP.P: My lord! I've an idea.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Sir I beg your pardon; but really if you have an idea, I'll be much obliged to you if you'll spare it me for my comedy.

SP.SPEAKER: ENN.
SP.P: In fact, I don't comprehend, I have read your die-all Epilogue, and—

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Oh then sir, I don't wonder at your having ideas.

SP.SPEAKER: ENN.
SP.P: Sir, I shall expect satisfaction.

SP.SPEAKER: VAP.
SP.P: Satisfaction! sir, if any one insults me I'll lick 'em on the stage sir, that's my way.

SP.SPEAKER: L. SCRATCH.
SP.P: Come, come, never mind him, the poor fellow is always talking of what he never had—Ideas in∣deed!—but come my boy Neville, may you be as happy as I am—I'm the happiest Peer alive, and I—when I die—

SP.SPEAKER: FLOR.
SP.P: Ay, I'll answer for his happiness by my own—Miss Courtney, notwithstanding my brother, I will still live in your eye, die in your lap—and be buried in your heart, and moreover I will stay with you both in England, and never return to Italy again.

SP.SPEAKER: LOU.
SP.P: Yes Florivelle.

LG.L: "And thus behold what ev'ry hour shall prove
